RT @4cm4k1 Anyone who knows @IlhanMN knows she isn‚Äôt anti-Semitic. Here, she reflects on the accusation thoughtfully. This has happened to @keithellison, too, & our local Jewish community will tell you that it‚Äôs simply false. https://twitter.com/IlhanMN/status/1087580647085039616 QT @IlhanMN Hi @bariweiss, 

You are correct when you say, 

‚ÄúPerhaps Ms. Omar is sincerely befuddled and not simply deflecting‚Äù 

In all sincerity, it was after my CNN interview that I heard from Jewish orgs. that my use of the word ‚ÄúHypnotize‚Äù and the ugly sentiment it holds was offensive. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Dxfc1FQUYAAq12B.jpg

There are many narratives of who and what I am, designed to demonize and vilify me.

It‚Äôs being building since my early days as an organizer. A concussion didn‚Äôt deter me and smears certainly won‚Äôt . I fought for my seat at the  table & will use it to fight a more peaceful world!

It is important that when you see oppression taking place - when you see our values being attacked as humans - you stand up, and it doesn't matter who the inhabitors of that particular region might be. 

Whether it is your father, your brother or your sister, you speak up.

As a survivor of war, the acts of war justified or not will always be acts of evil to me.

Like #MLK90, I unapologetically believe ‚ÄúMankind must put an end to war or war will put an end to mankind."

With that said, it is important to distinguish between criticizing a military action by a government and attacking a particular people of faith.

I will not shy away of criticism of any government when I see injustice ‚Äîwhether it be Saudi Arabia, Somalia, even our own government!

That statement came in the context of the Gaza War.

It‚Äôs now apparent to me that I spent lots of energy putting my 2012 tweet in context and little energy is disavowing the anti-semitic trope I unknowingly used, which is unfortunate and offensive.

In addition to his national service in the Senate and on civil rights, Harris served his country in the United States Army Air Corps. It's only fitting that Harris passed away on the national day of service he helped to bring into existence.

Harris met my father in the 1950s when they were young lawyers. They enjoyed a long friendship. My family appreciated Harris' support for Governor Casey over many campaigns and his service as U.S. Senator and as Sec. of the Department of Labor and Industry for our Commonwealth.

Harris stood with Dr. King during difficult times and never wavered in his enduring belief in civil rights. He worked with Sargent Shriver to found the Peace Corps, improving the lives of countless vulnerable people throughout the world.

From his work on the Civil Rights Commission in the 1950s to his work as Special Assistant to Pres Kennedy for Civil Rights and through his friendship with Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr, few Americans are more responsible for advancing the cause of civil rights than Harris Wofford.

Harris Wofford was a champion of justice and a man of uncommon courage who dedicated his life to service. https://twitter.com/washingtonpost/status/1087671229069312000 QT @washingtonpost Harris Wofford, civil rights activist who helped Kennedy win the White House, dies at 92 https://trib.al/ogqkqOB

Each day that the #TrumpShutdown drags on, our economy takes a toll. The @nytimes explains: https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/18/opinion/trump-government-shutdown.html

From Essex Junction, Vermont: "Some of us are young professionals just starting out... Some of us are the only source of income for our young families. Some of us are veterans. Now that we're facing work without pay, I worry for my colleagues' health, physical and mental."

From Manassas, Virginia: "We have already been punished by this situation; we had to entirely give up our Christmas and I had to look at my kids and ask that they hold their money so we could buy food if this shutdown continued."

From Denver, Colorado: "I'm getting worried about my mortgage payment coming up, I barely managed to ensure my student loans are paid for this month, and now I have to worry about food and other bills."

From Frederick, Maryland: "If the shutdown goes on much longer I will be forced to take money out of my kids' college funds and my retirement savings. That comes with penalities that I'll never get back."

From Lithonia, Georgia: "Many of our elderly residents are in jeopardy of not receiving their much-needed food stamps if the government shutdown does not end by the end of January 2019. These necessary funds for food are for basic survival due to their low incomes."
From Rockville, Maryland: "I have a significant pre-existing condition and worry for not only my health but the financial security of our family."

NEWS: I'm sending a letter along with 25 of my colleagues to @senatemajldr urging him to find the courage to vote to reopen the government.
